text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: BACKGROUND
label: BODY

text: Goals
label: BODY

text: The purpose of this Data Labeling project was for select members of the Data Nutrition
label: BODY

text: Project team to research and prototype possible quality measures for humanitarian
label: BODY

text: datasets that are hosted on the HDX platform, which is owned and managed by the UN
label: BODY

text: Centre for Humanitarian Data. The scope included:
label: BODY

text: User and Platform Research. We conducted user research with the Centre
label: BODY

text: team (and additional stakeholders suggested by the Centre) to learn about 1)
label: BODY

text: Different conceptions of data quality in the humanitarian sector; 2) How users
label: BODY

text: find and select data on HDX, including priority of criteria; 3) The current DPT /
label: BODY

text: HDX team QA workflow with regards to assessing data quality.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measurement Prototype. Building on user research and an
label: BODY

text: assessment of the state of the data and the needs in play, and using two
label: BODY

text: preselected datasets as examples, we prototyped a quality measures label for
label: BODY

text: HDX. The prototyping involved varying degrees of fidelity and was shaped by
label: BODY

text: feedback from the Centre team.
label: BODY

text: Preliminary thoughts on Scalability. Through research and prototyping,
label: BODY

text: we began to explore how this effort could scale, including paths toward
label: BODY

text: automatability. Our findings are discussed in this report.
label: BODY

text: Philosophy
label: BODY

text: The Data Nutrition Project is a non-profit initiative that formed in 2018 to develop tools
label: BODY

text: and practices to improve transparency into datasets. Our team is interdisciplinary,
label: BODY

text: and we leverage insights from a variety of fields, including product development, data
label: BODY

text: science, ethics, engineering, design, and education. Our approach with our Nutrition
label: BODY

text: Labels for Datasets is threefold: 1) We encourage the creation, documentation, and
label: BODY

text: publishing of higher quality data; 2) We enable transparency into datasets through our
label: BODY

text: legible, extensible, interactive framework; and 3) Our Labels provide education about
label: BODY

text: what kinds of information a user should ascertain before using a dataset. We bring
label: BODY

text: this approach into our work with clients, where we prioritize user-centered design,
label: BODY

text: realistic goals, and practitioner-focused outcomes, informed by our experience working
label: BODY

text: in data transparency initiatives and with the real tradeoffs and tensions faced by data
label: BODY

text: practitioners. In seeking to do work that is both applied and realizable, we aim to
label: BODY

text: provide not only a long-term vision but also a roadmap with recommendations for future
label: BODY

text: iterations of a project.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: II.
label: BODY

text: CHALLENGES
label: BODY

text: There are many challenges that can be impediments to dataset quality. This is certainly
label: BODY

text: the case in the humanitarian sector, where crises unfold quickly and data capture will
label: BODY

text: almost always be imperfect, often as a consequence of the need for rapid collection.
label: BODY

text: Furthermore, on a more philosophical level, the assigning of rankings, scores, or grades
label: BODY

text: to a dataset will always be tricky business, for the legitimacy of the scoring standards
label: BODY

text: themselves can undermine the effort for scoring in the first place. We believe it is useful
label: BODY

text: to explicitly enumerate these challenges before we describe our recommendations. The
label: BODY

text: latter were formed in light of the former, which will be familiar to the HDX team and to
label: BODY

text: others who have worked on dataset metrics, measures, and assessments.
label: BODY

text: Challenge 1 - Identifying scoring methods that are succinct while not overly simplistic
label: BODY

text: Scores are meant to provide information quickly and ease comparison, while inviting
label: BODY

text: further exploration. They can, however, risk being reductive or overly simplistic. This is
label: BODY

text: particularly difficult when comparing datasets whose provenances are entirely different.
label: BODY

text: A score that is too simplistic will not only be useless but may also seem arbitrary. A
label: BODY

text: single score to compare across inconsistent data types or domains may risk both.
label: BODY

text: Depending on the scoring framework, there is the additional challenge of validating
label: BODY

text: accuracy: what is the rubric by which this score was determined? How is accuracy of
label: BODY

text: evaluation defined and ensured?
label: BODY

text: Challenge 2 - Balancing scalable (quantitative) & comprehensive (qualitative) measures
label: BODY

text: Qualitative information helps mitigate some of the concerns above, as it is often more
label: BODY

text: context-aware than quantitative statistics alone. However, qualitative information
label: BODY

text: (such as detailed provenance information) is also resource-intensive to collect, often is
label: BODY

text: domain-specific, and is sometimes impossible to obtain, such as when provenance is
label: BODY

text: simply unknown. Conversely, quantitative measures can be easier to automate and thus
label: BODY

text: easier to scale, but they can miss nuance or context that is essential to understanding
label: BODY

text: the particulars of a dataset. The tension here is between usefulness and scalability; in
label: BODY

text: our experience, this is the most common challenge in dataset transparency efforts.
label: BODY

text: Challenge 3 - Communicating quality to motivate rather than disincentivize
label: BODY

text: Our hope is that quality measures will, in the short term, facilitate better data use
label: BODY

text: choices, and in the long term motivate the creation and publishing of better quality
label: BODY

text: data by changing user expectations and data collection habits. However, depending on
label: BODY

text: how measures are disclosed and how scores are determined, they could discourage
label: BODY

text: full transparency when sharing data in cases where increased transparency might
label: BODY

text: negatively affect a score. The challenge here is to motivate better quality data without
label: BODY

text: penalizing or disincentivizing current dataset owners from sharing data or disclosing
label: BODY

text: shortcomings. For example, over the course of our research, a data organization voiced
label: BODY

text: concern that their data was being marked “incomplete” even though it was “as good as
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: it possibly could have been’’ given a particular set of circumstances. It is important to
label: BODY

text: note that in some scenarios certain information cannot be ascertained and this should
label: BODY

text: not reflect negatively on the quality of the dataset.
label: BODY

text: Challenge 4 - Building a quality framework that balances flexibility with consistency
label: BODY

text: As the humanitarian sector changes over time with respect to crises and data needs,
label: BODY

text: any discrete quality metrics will also likely change. For these reasons, whatever is built
label: BODY

text: will need to be adaptable. However, consistency is also important, so that datasets from
label: BODY

text: different time periods can be compared, and so that dataset owners and site visitors can
label: BODY

text: develop familiarity and comfort with the site. For example, when and how do existing
label: BODY

text: datasets get re-evaluated under updated scoring rubrics? What is the right approach
label: BODY

text: to keeping information up to date (timely and punctual) that will be both robust and
label: BODY

text: scalable across thousands of datasets?  When or how will that score be altered or
label: BODY

text: downgraded as time goes on?
label: BODY

text: Challenge 5 - Determining responsibilities within the data pipeline
label: BODY

text: HDX is committed to hosting good quality data, and requires QA and other data
label: BODY

text: onboarding processes. However, HDX, like all organizations in the humanitarian sector,
label: BODY

text: has limited resources, with respect to time and personnel for validating datasets.
label: BODY

text: Furthermore, even if there were no resource constraints, there are always knowledge
label: BODY

text: gaps between on-the-ground domain expertise and data experts looking at raw or
label: BODY

text: processed data. This challenge is shared among all data validation efforts, and it
label: BODY

text: might be even more drastic in the domain of humanitarian data, where data collection
label: BODY

text: methods require agility, and thus context-awareness and domain knowledge is essential
label: BODY

text: for accurately interpreting or validating the data. However, HDX is extremely well-
label: BODY

text: positioned to build a process, and for that process to incorporate shared responsibility
label: BODY

text: for data-validation, as we discuss below.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: III.
label: BODY

text: KEY FINDINGS
label: BODY

text: The five-week sprint gave rise to a number of key findings, which informed our final
label: BODY

text: designs and recommendations.
label: BODY

text: Finding 1 - HDX is best positioned to define rather than assess quality
label: BODY

text: Due to the range of dataset types on HDX, limitations of domain knowledge, and
label: BODY

text: resource constraints, HDX is not well positioned to conduct quality assessments
label: BODY

text: for all datasets on its platform, and instead, HDX should focus that attention to
label: BODY

text: data types or categories that have been defined as critical, such as the Data
label: BODY

text: Grids. HDX is best positioned to
label: BODY

text: 1) Define the framework for “quality” of datasets on HDX (meaning define
label: BODY

text: what is getting collected and assessed);
label: BODY

text: 2) Facilitate the gathering of this information from data organizations;
label: BODY

text: 3) Provide a display of this information to data users on HDX, designed
label: BODY

text: in alignment with user needs.
label: BODY

text: Finding 2 - There is an opportunity to leverage existing quality measures
label: BODY

text: Data quality assessment is already conducted on HDX, albeit at different times
label: BODY

text: and displayed or communicated in disparate regions of the site. This provides
label: BODY

text: an opportunity, as a first step, to aggregate, prioritize, and organize information
label: BODY

text: that has already been gathered. Further ambitions to collect and validate data
label: BODY

text: that is not currently collected should come only after the current effort to bring
label: BODY

text: transparency and legibility to the valuable information that HDX already collects.
label: BODY

text: It is our belief that a phased approach, starting with the information already
label: BODY

text: collected, and expanding out from there to leverage the credibility of data
label: BODY

text: organizations, will be most suitable to HDX’s current infrastructure.
label: BODY

text: Finding 3 - Domain experts and third-party validators can provide
label: BODY

text: complementary value
label: BODY

text: Due to the variety of data types and domains on HDX, data content quality
label: BODY

text: assessment is likely to require verticalization (e.g. different approaches for GIS
label: BODY

text: data, CODs, etc). Considering the ranges of domain expertise required, and
label: BODY

text: the limited bandwidth on the Centre team, our recommendation, as stated in
label: BODY

text: Finding 1, is that the Centre define the parameters of “quality” through a set
label: BODY

text: of extended metadata that is to be displayed HDX, and then work with data
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: owners and third-party assessors who will be the ones to contribute much
label: BODY

text: of this extended metadata. This would follow HDX’s work to aggregate the
label: BODY

text: information already collected, and determine the best design approach for
label: BODY

text: communicating this information to users. Many data organizations have quality
label: BODY

text: frameworks or assessments for their own data, and these could be indicated on
label: BODY

text: HDX to communicate things like known issues and certain strengths of a dataset
label: BODY

text: within its domain. Working in collaboration with these organizations can lend
label: BODY

text: institutional validation to these quality frameworks – which, either independently
label: BODY

text: or alongside additional support, could motivate third parties to work with HDX –
label: BODY

text: and would provide domain expertise to HDX and its users. Using these external
label: BODY

text: third-party-determined metrics also encourages other organizations to consider
label: BODY

text: adapting their use frameworks to include quality, which can drive cultural change
label: BODY

text: around responsible data usage.
label: BODY

text: Finding 4 - Automation of QA and assessment tasks can enable scale
label: BODY

text: While there is some initial groundwork required to prepare for automating certain
label: BODY

text: QA tasks, we believe that HDX investing the time to move in this direction will,
label: BODY

text: in the long run, enable quality measures to be assessed and applied at scale.
label: BODY

text: For example, automating the collection of certain metadata (such as restrictions
label: BODY

text: around API use, required metadata through API collection, or requiring the use of
label: BODY

text: HXL) can make it easier to enforce and collect technical quality information about
label: BODY

text: datasets. We know that HDX has done a lot of work toward formatting datasets
label: BODY

text: into HXL and advocating for others to do the same. We understand that this is
label: BODY

text: no small feat, but if HXL can be more widely adopted, this would enable greater
label: BODY

text: interoperability, comparability, and analysis.
label: BODY

text: Finding 5 - Primary use case is data selection, which can ultimately be
label: BODY

text: supported through metrics comparison
label: BODY

text: Through our conversations and interviews, we learned that the primary reason for
label: BODY

text: having quality measures included on the platform is to improve dataset selection,
label: BODY

text: with additional use cases including dataset comparison (choosing among
label: BODY

text: several on HDX, wanting to quickly ascertain which is better for a certain need)
label: BODY

text: or dataset combination (merging several to cover a bigger geographic region
label: BODY

text: or to otherwise extend a particular dataset). The availability of legible, digestible
label: BODY

text: measures, such as format, update frequency, and uses and restrictions, permits
label: BODY

text: users to quickly scan for their particular needs. We recommend prioritizing
label: BODY

text: information that is already available, and in later phases collecting (and
label: BODY

text: collaborating with others to collect) additional information that can bring even
label: BODY

text: more value to dataset users.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: IV.
label: BODY

text: APPROACH & DIRECTIONS
label: BODY

text: We explored quality measures on the HDX platform through a tailored 5-week discovery
label: BODY

text: sprint in a three-part inquiry: 1) Researching data quality principles in the context of
label: BODY

text: humanitarian data and the existing platform; 2) Developing several prototype directions
label: BODY

text: building on this principles-based foundation drawing on our expertise in data quality
label: BODY

text: “labels”; 3) Refining our direction and recommended implementation strategy based on
label: BODY

text: feedback from the Centre.
label: BODY

text: Research
label: BODY

text: Our team spent the first two weeks researching background materials and interviewing
label: BODY

text: diverse stakeholders. We read and analyzed approximately a dozen reports about data
label: BODY

text: quality principles in the humanitarian sector (published by HDX, UNICEF, UK AID, IOM,
label: BODY

text: OCHA, ICRC, GAHI, DSEG, GSQAF, including others) in order to build an understanding
label: BODY

text: of quality measures on the HDX platform. We sketched a matrix aligning and comparing
label: BODY

text: principles across several major organizations (compared primarily to GDQAF principles,
label: BODY

text: which were most commonly cited as baseline) in order to better understand these
label: BODY

text: concepts in the context of HDX (fig. 1). Notably, we saw a gap in the literature published
label: BODY

text: by HDX around “credibility,” so we sketched this into the matrix (in light blue).
label: BODY

text: In parallel, we conducted interviews with stakeholders that represented key points along
label: BODY

text: the data collection, processing, hosting, and use timeline, including data partners (IOM,
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team) and several within the Centre (Data Partnerships,
label: BODY

text: Data Responsibility, organization onboarding, product development, quality assessment
label: BODY

text: process, and others), in order to understand how the Centre thinks about quality, to
label: BODY

text: learn about existing mechanisms for identifying and surfacing quality issues, and to
label: BODY

text: explore future scenarios for expanding or adjusting quality assessment practices.
label: BODY

text: Figure 1. Matrix aligning data
label: BODY

text: quality principles across several
label: BODY

text: organizations, with HDX in blue.
label: BODY

text: Full size matrix included in
label: BODY

text: appendix.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: Prototype directions
label: BODY

text: Based on the research and interviews conducted in the first two weeks of our sprint,
label: BODY

text: the DNP team developed four potential paths forward to highlight specific data quality
label: BODY

text: principles. These were:
label: BODY

text: Comparability: features to support dataset selection
label: BODY

text: Throughout the interviews, we heard that a primary use case for data quality
label: BODY

text: assessment on HDX (and more broadly in the sector) was the enabling of dataset
label: BODY

text: selection, either for a particular need at hand, to join with other external or proprietary
label: BODY

text: data (e.g. Combine several datasets about a particular geography), or to compare
label: BODY

text: against similar datasets to assess which is best aligned for a particular use (e.g.
label: BODY

text: Identifying which administrative boundary dataset is appropriate if there are several to
label: BODY

text: choose from). To support this particular use case of dataset selection, which we felt was
label: BODY

text: best aligned to the data principle of comparability, we proposed features that support
label: BODY

text: the direct comparing and contrasting of datasets based on metadata comparison (fig. 2)
label: BODY

text: Figure 2.  Prototype
label: BODY

text: sketches of features to
label: BODY

text: support the comparing and
label: BODY

text: contrasting of metadata on
label: BODY

text: similar datasets.
label: BODY

text: 2. Credibility: leveraging trust in organizations
label: BODY

text: From the earliest conversations, data organizations and the Centre teams stressed the
label: BODY

text: critical dependency between data quality and data collection and processing practices.
label: BODY

text: In fact, although there were several measures and principles of data quality that came
label: BODY

text: “after” the processing of the data – such as freshness, accessibility, and interpretability –
label: BODY

text: some of the most salient measures could only be assessed by those most familiar with
label: BODY

text: the origin of the data itself (fig. 3). This highlighted not only the importance of but also
label: BODY

text: the reliance upon data organizations to help surface data quality on HDX.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: Figure 3. Aligning the data pipeline to quality principles and responsible parties highlights the critical
label: BODY

text: relationship between the data organization and HDX for the assessment and communication of data
label: BODY

text: quality.
label: BODY

text: Our second prototype aimed to leverage trust in organizations based on their data
label: BODY

text: practices and commitment to data quality as a proxy for the data quality principle of
label: BODY

text: credibility. For this approach, our recommendation (which follows the initial work
label: BODY

text: performed by DNP team member and 2021 Strategic Communications Data Fellow
label: BODY

text: Kasia Chmielinski), HDX would build a framework for organization trust “levels”
label: BODY

text: that signal an active, relational approach towards quality: one that depends on the
label: BODY

text: organization that produces or publishes the dataset. Datasets would then qualitatively
label: BODY

text: inherit the credibility from the organization that produced them, with the organization
label: BODY

text: serving as a proxy for responsible data collection and processing practices (fig. 4).
label: BODY

text: Figure 4. Prototype sketches of a dataset with a
label: BODY

text: “level 3” trust organization indicator as a proxy
label: BODY

text: for the data quality principle of credibility.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: 3. Completeness, timeliness: assessing metadata completeness
label: BODY

text: The last two prototype directions are related to fitness for purpose - assessing whether
label: BODY

text: what is represented in the dataset is appropriate for use (complete, timely, relevant,
label: BODY

text: accurate).  We found fitness for purpose metrics to be the most challenging due to the
label: BODY

text: distribution of responsibility in dataset management, and the realities of data collection
label: BODY

text: in humanitarian situations. Stated simply, it is very hard to assess quality without an
label: BODY

text: ideal “ground truth” dataset against which to compare, or without access to information
label: BODY

text: about the collection and processing practices of the data owner. To facilitate our
label: BODY

text: analysis, we approached these measures along two axes: the assessor (data owner vs.
label: BODY

text: third party), and the type of assessment (qualitative vs. quantitative) (fig. 5). The resulting
label: BODY

text: matrix helps clarify four directions: qualitative (not easily scorable) assessment at two
label: BODY

text: levels of granularity, where the data owner can be much more detailed than a third
label: BODY

text: party, and two quantitative (more easily scored or ranked) approaches, one domain-
label: BODY

text: specific (e.g. GIS data quality, ranked by the data owner) and the other focused on
label: BODY

text: adherence to a metadata or technical standard (e.g. metadata completeness, in this
label: BODY

text: case conducted by HDX).
label: BODY

text: Building off this analysis, our third prototype direction falls within the third-party
label: BODY

text: quantitative assessment for completeness and timeliness: measuring and reporting
label: BODY

text: adherence to standards of metadata completeness. This version, along with the former
label: BODY

text: (Credibility of Trusted Orgs) and the one that follows, combine for our recommendation
label: BODY

text: to the Centre team. In this version, HDX builds a framework of expectations of metadata
label: BODY

text: standards and provides a score or indicator on whether a dataset meets that standard.
label: BODY

text: For example, HDX could incentivize higher data quality through a measurement that
label: BODY

text: assigns a higher score (or ranking) for the use of automatic data submission, the use of
label: BODY

text: standard data elements (such as P-codes or HXL), or attestation of a third party review.
label: BODY

text: For simplicity of communication, these metadata could be categorized into sections
label: BODY

text: (such as “Trust,” “Content Quality,” “Uses,” etc.) (fig. 6).
label: BODY

text: Figure 5 (left). Quadrant analysis of fitness for purpose
label: BODY

text: measures along two axes: responsible party (data owner /
label: BODY

text: third-party) and type of measure (qualitative / quantitative).
label: BODY

text: Figure 6 (right). Prototype for a “quality label” that
label: BODY

text: assesses and highlights metadata completeness across a
label: BODY

text: number of categories and against a common framework.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: 4. Relevance, accuracy: assessing fitness for purpose
label: BODY

text: The final prototype approach, assessing fitness for purpose in alignment with data
label: BODY

text: principles relevance and accuracy, most likely requires direct input from the
label: BODY

text: data owner or a party that is familiar with the entire lifecycle of data collection and
label: BODY

text: processing (see the left hand side of the quadrant matrix fig. 5). This is because it is
label: BODY

text: extremely difficult, if not impossible, to understand the quality of content contained
label: BODY

text: within a dataset without understanding the context in which it was gathered, processed,
label: BODY

text: and how it will be used. This requires both knowledge of the data collection process as
label: BODY

text: well as significant domain expertise.
label: BODY

text: Our suggestion for this approach is thus to acknowledge the dependency between
label: BODY

text: HDX and the data owner (organization) and leverage structured frameworks for the
label: BODY

text: communication of dataset quality information. For example, HDX could partner with
label: BODY

text: third party organizations that certify certain data quality domains (e.g. GIS data, CODs,
label: BODY

text: boundary data, education or health data) and when datasets achieve that certification,
label: BODY

text: HDX could communicate that information on the platform. In some instances, HDX
label: BODY

text: may also be a certifier – the Data Grids are a good example of this – but for the sake of
label: BODY

text: scaling, expanding to third party certifications will be less resource-intensive and more
label: BODY

text: applicable to the breadth of datasets within the HDX platform. An additional option
label: BODY

text: might be for HDX to work with particular data organizations to surface their internal
label: BODY

text: quality measures through standardized metadata fields that, while not consistent with
label: BODY

text: respect to content across data organizations, would be a consistent field that appears
label: BODY

text: on all datasets regardless of organization or domain (e.g. a “domain-specific quality
label: BODY

text: measure” field that could be defined differently across organizations and domains). For
label: BODY

text: example, in the figure below (fig. 7), HDX has defined a portion of the metadata structure
label: BODY

text: to include both a “self-reported QA adherence” from the Data Organization as well as a
label: BODY

text: “domain-specific metric” built by a third party.
label: BODY

text: Figure 7. Prototype sketch of Content
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures that include quality
label: BODY

text: certifications from HDX, Data Org
label: BODY

text: / Owner and Third-Party expert
label: BODY

text: organizations. These could be binary
label: BODY

text: (pass / fail) or quantitative (e.g. a score).
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDATIONS & DESIGNS
label: BODY

text: Recommendations
label: BODY

text: From our four prototype directions outlined above, and integrating feedback from
label: BODY

text: the Centre team, we recommend a combination of prototype directions 2, 3, and 4,
label: BODY

text: organized into three phases of work. Detailed work plans and sketches for Phase 1 are
label: BODY

text: included in this report.
label: BODY

text: We also share recommendations for how to approach the continuation of these
label: BODY

text: explorations in Phases 2 and 3, and include a preview (low fidelity sketch) of how
label: BODY

text: extended information that might be included in Phase 3 could appear on HDX. The
label: BODY

text: phased approach enables HDX to prioritize the information that is already available,
label: BODY

text: while beginning to build an on-ramp for further work that will require additional
label: BODY

text: resources and infrastructure. A summary of the phases is included below, and discussed
label: BODY

text: in more detail in Section VI.
label: BODY

text: Phase 1 - Fully scoped, ready to implement
label: BODY

text: Aggregate and make easily accessible the content that HDX already collects with
label: BODY

text: a specialized Quality Measures pane on the HDX site. This Quality Measures
label: BODY

text: pane is divided into four parts: Use, Trust & Safety, Content Quality, and
label: BODY

text: Technical Specs. The measures in each section are summed, not as a score, but
label: BODY

text: as an indicator for comparability, and an indication of the value of transparency
label: BODY

text: into dataset information. These sums are visible in the search view on HDX as at-
label: BODY

text: a-glance indicators about dataset quality measures.
label: BODY

text: Phase 2 - High-level spec, requires additional research and design
label: BODY

text: Create an organization review and vetting process that allows for trusted orgs to
label: BODY

text: serve as a proxy – or at least an additional indicator – for dataset credibility, and
label: BODY

text: introduce org badges into the Quality Measures pane; automate QA processes
label: BODY

text: where possible; begin research into domain-specific quality measures.
label: BODY

text: Phase 3 - High-level spec, requires additional research & design
label: BODY

text: Collect additional quality measures through third-party organization QA
label: BODY

text: processes; introduce self-reporting assessment for domain-specific quality
label: BODY

text: measures; implement dataset comparison suggestions of “similar datasets,” and
label: BODY

text: consider adding further measures pending user feedback from Phases 1 and 2.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: Additional notes on our recommendations:
label: BODY

text: Our approach involved prototyping on real datasets. This proved to be an
label: BODY

text: essential part of our process; it enabled our work to be grounded in the
label: BODY

text: particulars of the HDX context. We will follow this model for any future work
label: BODY

text: with HDX.
label: BODY

text: Based on our research and interviews, completeness, accuracy, and relevance
label: BODY

text: were the quality measures that were most useful, and HDX already collects
label: BODY

text: certain information that has indicators for these areas. The work in Phase 1
label: BODY

text: involves organizing this information into a legible knowledge structure, and
label: BODY

text: designing it in a visible and easily accessible way. The chart in Section VI below
label: BODY

text: (fig. 12) Indicates where and when this information is collected, and possible
label: BODY

text: answers for each field.
label: BODY

text: Based on the needs of HDX users and the circumstances – 20K+ disparate
label: BODY

text: datasets, limited resources for additional dataset security – we determined that
label: BODY

text: HDX ought to build frameworks for measuring metadata completeness and,
label: BODY

text: additionally, seek out quality certifications (likely conducted by third parties, but
label: BODY

text: could also be conducted internally by HDX).
label: BODY

text: Designs
label: BODY

text: DNP created three Phase 1 designs (a template + two dataset-specific versions), a
label: BODY

text: “search” view, and a Phase 3 preview of the dataset comparison section. Full resolution
label: BODY

text: designs are included in the Appendix.
label: BODY

text: Figure 8. Phase 1 content in Quality Measures Pane on HDX site.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: Figure 9. HDX search view with Quality Measure counts.
label: BODY

text: Figure 10. Views of Quality Measures Panes (Phase 1) for two example datasets.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: Figure 11. “Similar Datasets” comparison sketch, to be refined in Phase 3.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: VI.
label: BODY

text: ROADMAP & IMPLEMENTATION
label: BODY

text: Phase 1
label: BODY

text: Approach
label: BODY

text: We recommend creating a new Quality Measures pane (alongside the Data &
label: BODY

text: Resources and Metadata panes) for the HDX dataset landing page. This view will
label: BODY

text: consolidate existing measures from across HDX into one view that gives users a quick
label: BODY

text: overview of dataset information and proxies for quality, organized into four sections:
label: BODY

text: Use | Trust & Safety | Content Quality | Technical Specs
label: BODY

text: The technical needs for this should be minimal, and implementation process could
label: BODY

text: include: 1) Implementing the prototype on HDX’s staging server; 2) Soliciting feedback
label: BODY

text: on the prototype from key stakeholders, integrating feedback where possible; and 3)
label: BODY

text: Rolling out the measures design to HDX. Because all of the information present in the
label: BODY

text: Phase 1 prototype is already collected, it would be a matter of consolidating information
label: BODY

text: rather than creating new information or processes. Below (fig. 12)is a chart of the
label: BODY

text: information contained in the Phase 1 designs, and where that information comes from in
label: BODY

text: the HDX workflow.
label: BODY

text: Technical Considerations
label: BODY

text: Phase 1 involves no database changes, and minimal back-end implementation. It will
label: BODY

text: focus primarily on front-end implementation for HDX, and soliciting feedback from
label: BODY

text: stakeholders.
label: BODY

text: Database/DevOps. The data needed for the Phase 1 measures view exists
label: BODY

text: within HDX already, meaning there should be no database migration/change
label: BODY

text: considerations.
label: BODY

text: Back-end. Implementation would be focused on making sure all of the
label: BODY

text: necessary quality measures are available to the front-end website. While many
label: BODY

text: of these are already available to the front-end, such as last-updated date and
label: BODY

text: caveats, some things may not be readily available, such as whether a QA
label: BODY

text: check has been conducted. This would involve an audit of existing data access
label: BODY

text: endpoints, with the potential need to implement a few new back-end endpoints
label: BODY

text: for existing information. It may also require reformatting some of the back-end
label: BODY

text: endpoints to ensure the information needed by the front-end is in the right format.
label: BODY

text: Front-end. Front-end work would be the most significant portion of this phase. It
label: BODY

text: would include implementing back-end requests and an accessible, localizable UX.
label: BODY

text: Feedback. It will be important to have a clearly defined list of stakeholders
label: BODY

text: from whom to get feedback on Phase 1 designs, and clear reasons for why
label: BODY

text: they are being chosen, and the kind of feedback sought. It will be important to
label: BODY

text: set limitations for the scope of their feedback, so that they understand what is
label: BODY

text: possible in Phase 1.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: Phase 1 is intentionally a consolidation and “surfacing and organizing what is already
label: BODY

text: there” phase and thus should not require substantial technical work.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Figure 12. Phase 1 Quality Measures table including source of information and response parameters.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: Further recommendations
label: BODY

text: Phase 2
label: BODY

text: Phases 2 and 3 research and designs could be explored in future engagements.
label: BODY

text: Approach
label: BODY

text: Phase 2 has three specific foci: 1) determining measures for and assessing
label: BODY

text: organizational trust, 2) creating capacity for longer-term quality measures development,
label: BODY

text: and 3) research on domain-specific measures. For organizational trust, the goal would
label: BODY

text: be to come up with an architecture for measuring an organization’s data processes,
label: BODY

text: which would be used as a proxy for the credibility of the organization’s datasets. This
label: BODY

text: would then be easily viewable as a quality indicator. The element of creating capacity
label: BODY

text: for QA automation would include identifying the components of the QA process that
label: BODY

text: are automatable, and implementing changes in technical workflows to create this
label: BODY

text: automation. The third component of this phase involves researching domain-specific
label: BODY

text: quality measures. For example, how is quality evaluated for GIS infrastructure datasets,
label: BODY

text: or food security datasets? Domain-specific quality measures will add value to dataset
label: BODY

text: review and may reveal potential avenues for automated assessment.
label: BODY

text: Technical Considerations
label: BODY

text: For each of the three components of Phase 2, technical considerations would
label: BODY

text: vary based on the capacity of HDX. A narrative exploring the range of technical
label: BODY

text: considerations (from limited capacity to high capacity) would be included after
label: BODY

text: conducting further research.
label: BODY

text: Phase 3
label: BODY

text: Approach
label: BODY

text: Following on the recommendations from Phases 1 & 2, Phase 3 would enable a more
label: BODY

text: comprehensive quality metrics interface. This would include implementing the research
label: BODY

text: from Phase 2 on domain-specific quality measures and either 1) soliciting third party
label: BODY

text: organizations to build certification processes for these metrics, or 2) proposing a self-
label: BODY

text: assessment for agreed-upon domain-specific measures.
label: BODY

text: With more comprehensive quality measures, HDX will have the information available for
label: BODY

text: meaningful dataset comparison. This comparison could be displayed in a section called
label: BODY

text: “Similar Datasets,” enabling users to quickly compare across HDX datasets along the
label: BODY

text: metrics that are most important for them, and thus choose the best data for their use
label: BODY

text: cases.
label: BODY

text: Rationale
label: BODY

text: In our research on Common Operational Datasets (CODs) and GIS road-mapping
label: BODY

text: datasets, we discovered that there were some specific methods for quality analysis that
label: BODY

text: applied to all datasets in a given domain, but not beyond that domain. CODs have their
label: BODY

text: own quality metrics framework and third party certification; GIS road-mapping datasets
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: tend to have a standardized structure that most dataset creators use. Consequently, it
label: BODY

text: seems feasible that the findings from Phase 2 on domain-specific datasets could be
label: BODY

text: rolled into third party certification in some cases, or automated analysis in others (where
label: BODY

text: data is already informally standardized).
label: BODY

text: And, while the measures in Phase 1 are a helpful starting point to assess quality,
label: BODY

text: more analysis is needed for robust dataset comparison. The addition of third party
label: BODY

text: certifications and automated analyses by domain will provide the content for such
label: BODY

text: comparison. Technical considerations for Phase 3 would be enumerated after the
label: BODY

text: research, development, and design for Phases 2 and 3.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: VII.
label: BODY

text: ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS
label: BODY

text: Impact on existing data processes and systems
label: BODY

text: Currently, data organizations upload their datasets to HDX either in bulk (using the
label: BODY

text: HDX / CKAN APIs) or manually (using the upload form process). Many dataset
label: BODY

text: quality measures are already collected during these processes, and we recommend
label: BODY

text: that additional information could be gathered through updating the API and the form.
label: BODY

text: Critically, our Phase 1 recommendation does not require this additional infrastructure,
label: BODY

text: and instead utilizes only information that HDX already collects. In Phase 2 and beyond,
label: BODY

text: there are additional automated and manual processes in which more metadata is
label: BODY

text: gathered, some of which could be leveraged as quality measures. The particulars of this
label: BODY

text: information - what is gathered and when, and what opportunities there are to collect
label: BODY

text: more data automatically or otherwise – require further exploration.
label: BODY

text: Inclusion of quality measures in future technical projects
label: BODY

text: Over the course of our engagement with the Centre, we learned that there are
label: BODY

text: several additional projects in flight that could overlap with the further collection and
label: BODY

text: surfacing of quality metrics on HDX. These projects include the Data-as-a-Service
label: BODY

text: work (ArgoDesign) and shifts towards workflow management of the QA process. It
label: BODY

text: is an open question as to how and whether these projects could address the quality
label: BODY

text: measurements initiative. As these projects get scoped further, we recommend surfacing
label: BODY

text: any possible overlaps early and identifying what, if anything, can be added to more
label: BODY

text: quickly enable the collection and surfacing of quality measures on HDX.
label: BODY

text: Trusted Org & Third Party Certification program definition
label: BODY

text: As outlined above, for Phase 2 would entail research for two initiatives that leverage
label: BODY

text: external organizations as proxies for credibility: 1) A trusted organization program, which
label: BODY

text: results in a trust score or level that is inherited by all datasets from that organization;
label: BODY

text: and 2) Beginning research on a third party certification program, to be implemented
label: BODY

text: in Phase 3, that enables third party validators of content quality (most likely domain
label: BODY

text: expertise) to report whether a dataset meets assessment criteria. Although we
label: BODY

text: have drafted some potential metadata options, including a trust level or score for
label: BODY

text: organizations and an area in the UI to hold “certifications” (which could sit within the
label: BODY

text: quality measurements pane described in Phase 1), further research is required to define
label: BODY

text: the set of metadata and the processes of collecting that information; this would include
label: BODY

text: stakeholder interviews with current contributing orgs, some of the (informally) trusted
label: BODY

text: orgs, and additional third party organizations.
label: BODY

text: “Compare” feature dependencies
label: BODY

text: Phase 3 considerations include the addition of domain-specific metadata, third-party
label: BODY

text: certification metrics, and the ability to compare and see additional, related datasets
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: on HDX. Multiple conversations with the Centre and its users highlighted the critical
label: BODY

text: importance of data selection. However, the notion of comparing and contrasting
label: BODY

text: datasets requires standardized metadata, some of which is already collected, but
label: BODY

text: much of which is not programmatically accessible. In particular, the usefulness of the
label: BODY

text: “compare” feature, which requires additional research but could appear, for example,
label: BODY

text: within the “Quality Measures” tab on the dataset page or the search results returned
label: BODY

text: after submitting a query – increases significantly with the inclusion of technical
label: BODY

text: information about the dataset that would be made available through the HXL-ation
label: BODY

text: process. This is no doubt a challenge, considering that the majority of datasets are not
label: BODY

text: yet HXLated. There is an open question about how much metadata must be available
label: BODY

text: on HDX datasets for the “compare” feature  to be useful.
label: BODY

text: Resource identification
label: BODY

text: Each of the recommendations made in this report will require resources from the Centre
label: BODY

text: and, in some cases, beyond the Centre. This echoes a common refrain in technology
label: BODY

text: processes and projects about resource management, and thus requires consideration
label: BODY

text: within the context of roadmap prioritization across the larger team. Phase 1 will require
label: BODY

text: design and technical resources for implementation, though we have tried to scope this
label: BODY

text: phase to be relatively small with respect to back-end changes. Phases 2 and 3 will
label: BODY

text: require additional resources, especially for the trusted org and third party validation
label: BODY

text: programs and UX / Product Management / Development resources for the “compare
label: BODY

text: datasets” feature set. Additionally, any work with third parties requires not only building
label: BODY

text: but also maintaining relationships over time.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: VIII.
label: BODY

text: CONCLUSION
label: BODY

text: This report outlines the findings from a five-week research and design sprint,
label: BODY

text: undertaken between February into early March 2023, by the DNP team, to deliver
label: BODY

text: a set of implementable prototypes for quality metrics indicators on the HDX site
label: BODY

text: (Phase 1). While the process included contending with some known – and some new
label: BODY

text: – challenges, we are pleased to share that this sprint has concluded in a number of
label: BODY

text: valuable  findings, a concrete set of designs based on content that is already available
label: BODY

text: on or collected by HDX, a determination of the path forward of a  summation “score”
label: BODY

text: that indicates whether the information is available, rather than an normative grade
label: BODY

text: on the information itself, and prospects for future work (Phases 2 and 3). We are
label: BODY

text: also delivering complete prototypes of two distinct datasets as an illustration of the
label: BODY

text: information that can be conveyed in the Phase 1 quality measures pane of the HDX site.
label: BODY

text: In summary, HDX already attends to dataset quality. We found that a lot could be gained
label: BODY

text: simply by consolidating disparate elements from the HDX upload and review process,
label: BODY

text: and making this information readily available to dataset users. We also found that
label: BODY

text: summing the information that is provided within four discrete sections (with a numerator
label: BODY

text: but no denominator) enables for a gentle indicator of quantity of information without
label: BODY

text: penalizing others for not having that information.
label: BODY

text: Many fields that involve data-driven decision making are only now starting to ask
label: BODY

text: questions about dataset quality – questions that HDX has already answered and started
label: BODY

text: to build into its systems. With a concrete, phased approach, HDX can implement quality
label: BODY

text: measures for data in a way that meets its users’ needs and sets an example for many
label: BODY

text: other fields. DNP looks forward to continued collaboration in this process.
label: BODY

text: Quality Measures for Humanitarian Data
label: BODY

text: IX.
label: BODY
